column10: Driver just ran the red light after it had turned -- a good 3-4 seconds afte rit switched.

Entered the crosswalk and driver of a maroon/red SUV made eye contact with me then sped up. Driver then proceeded to the light at slaters lane/potomac greens drive, and began honking at a car ahead of them.

People consistently double park; drivers speed across PGD from one parking lot to the other, not looking for pedestrians; capital bikeshare in this location; cyclists on sidewalk because  the cars are a mess, double parked and not parked in legal spots.

As she approached the stop sign at a high rate of speed on Hunting Creek Drive, driver was looking left down Massey Lane to see if she could continue on. If I had not yelled at her to slow down, she most likely would not have seen me.

SUV  traveling north on N St Asaph and making a left turn onto Wythe almost hit an elderly pedestrain in the crosswalk. It was very close and scary to see. But this is a regular occurrence in Old Town.

I passed the light to cross Potomac Ave and waited for one car traveling  southbound who was clearly not going to yield to pass. Once I was almost halway across the street, the driver sped up passed in front of me. He didn't see me until after he passed.

I was crossing the street in the crosswalk during my run, when a car speeds up a bit and moves to the other sde of the road around me. I signed for him to slow down. The man turned around, parked his car started yelling. I was wearing reflective gear.
Ongoing â€“ bikes going whenever they want, not obeying lights
Drivers turning left from main line ave onto Potomac towards rt 1 frequently do not yield to pedestrians

I was crossing north to south over Slater's Lane on the western crosswalk when a car turning left from Portner Rd. to go west on Slater's Lane failed to yield and almost hit my stroller with my son in it. I was in the crosswalk with an active walk signal.

Driver in SUV going northbound on Hwy 1 made right turn using slip lane right as we were about to enter the crosswalk and didn't appear to slow down on approach. We had the WALK signal as well.; Slip Lane

The crosswalk signal automatically turns on for pedestrians when crossing over Potomac Greens Drive but it doesn't automatically turn on for pedestrians crossing over Slaters Lane. Crossing Slaters Lane is the busier pedestrian way and therefore I feel like it should be set up to automatically turn on the walk signal.
column21: It's not logical that the busier pedestrian crosswalk isn't automatically set up to turn on. Cars don't look to yield if the walk signal isn't on but if you can't catch the button in time, you won't get a walk signal.
